importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article's publication marks the announcement of Pakistan's successful launch of its first hyperspectral satellite, a significant development in national space capabilities.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, marking a major milestone in its space programme.
The satellite was launched by Pakistan’s space agency SUPARCO from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025.
Hyperspectral technology enables detection of subtle chemical and material changes on Earth, useful for agriculture, environmental monitoring, and disaster management.
The satellite is expected to enhance national capabilities in precision agriculture, water resource management, urban planning, and geohazard risk identification.
Pakistan sees the satellite as a key advancement for development initiatives like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC).
The launch reflects a strategic partnership between Pakistan and China in peaceful space exploration.
Two other satellites (EO-1 and KS-1) are already fully operational, indicating a growing trend in Pakistan’s space programme.
It may take about two months to calibrate the H1 satellite before it becomes fully operational.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pakistan is the nation launching its first hyperspectral satellite, highlighting its technological advancement and strategic goals in agriculture, disaster management, and infrastructure development.

namedEntities.name: SUPARCO
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SUPARCO is responsible for the launch and management of Pakistan’s space missions, including the H1 satellite, and plays a central role in advancing national space capabilities.

namedEntities.name: H1 satellite
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite provides advanced Earth observation capabilities that support agriculture, environmental monitoring, and disaster response, marking a key step in Pakistan’s space ambitions.

namedEntities.name: Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A space launch facility in China’s northwest
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The launch site in China’s Jiuquan is where the H1 satellite was launched, reflecting Pakistan’s international collaboration with China in space technology.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China hosts the launch site for Pakistan’s satellite, underscoring a strategic space partnership between Pakistan and China, especially relevant to the CPEC and peaceful space cooperation.

namedEntities.name: China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major infrastructure development linking China’s Xinjiang province to Pakistan’s Gwadar Port
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The hyperspectral satellite’s geohazard monitoring capabilities are expected to support CPEC’s infrastructure planning and environmental sustainability goals.

namedEntities.name: EO-1
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Pakistan satellite already in orbit
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: EO-1 is one of two fully operational satellites in Pakistan’s space programme, showing the country’s growing capacity in satellite-based Earth observation.

namedEntities.name: KS-1
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Pakistan satellite already in orbit
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: KS-1 is another fully operational satellite, indicating that Pakistan’s space programme is expanding and maturing with multiple active missions.

namedEntities.name: Hyperspectral technology
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A remote sensing technology detecting subtle material changes on Earth
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This technology enables Pakistan to monitor crop health, water resources, and natural disasters more precisely than traditional satellites.

namedEntities.name: Precision agriculture
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A method of farming using data-driven techniques
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite will support precision agriculture by providing real-time data on crop quality and soil conditions, improving food security.

namedEntities.name: Environmental monitoring
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The ongoing observation of environmental conditions
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The satellite supports environmental monitoring for climate resilience and ecosystem health across Pakistan.

namedEntities.name: Disaster management
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The process of preparing for and responding to natural disasters
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hyperspectral data can help detect early signs of landslides or flood damage, improving disaster response and planning.

namedEntities.name: Urban planning
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The design and development of cities and infrastructure
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The satellite data can inform better urban planning by identifying land use and environmental changes in growing cities.

namedEntities.name: Geohazard risk identification
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The detection of natural risks like landslides or earthquakes
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The satellite enables Pakistan to monitor and predict geohazards, enhancing national safety and infrastructure resilience.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre, marking a significant step in its space programme. Developed by SUPARCO, the satellite uses advanced hyperspectral technology to detect subtle material changes on Earth, enabling improved monitoring of agriculture, water resources, environmental health, and geohazards. The launch strengthens Pakistan’s strategic partnership with China and supports development goals such as the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). While H1 will take about two months to calibrate before full operation, it joins two already operational satellites (EO-1 and KS-1), showing a growing capacity in national space capabilities.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
